description.plain:
A true pop icon, Robyn “Rihanna” Fenty is a singer, actress, and businesswoman from Saint Michael, Barbados. She was first discovered by American record producer Evan Rogers in 2003 and later signed a contract to Def Jam Recordings in 2004, after auditioning for its then-president, JAY-Z.

The following year, in 2005, she released her debut album Music of the Sun and its follow-up, A Girl Like Me, in 2006. Both albums did well commercially, but it wasn’t until the release of her third album, Good Girl Gone Bad, in 2007 that poised Rihanna as an international pop star. It became her first album to receive a Grammy nomination (seven to be exact) and features one of her biggest hits, “Umbrella.”

Moving onto 2009, Rihanna released her fourth studio album, Rated R. It featured a darker and more atmospheric tone from her previous albums. She released her fifth studio album, Loud, the next year in 2010. It marked her return to making dance-pop records. That summer, she featured on Eminem’s smash hit, “Love the Way You Lie” and is one of her most popular features of all time.

Rihanna continued her album streak in 2011 when she released her sixth studio album, Talk That Talk. It’s lead-single, “We Found Love,” became her biggest hit to date, topping the Billboard Hot 100 for ten weeks. The next year, in 2012, she released her seventh studio album, Unapologetic.

2013 ended Rihanna three-year album streak, taking a short break from recording music. Instead, she featured on songs like Wale’s “Bad (Remix)” and Eminem’s “The Monster.” The following year, in 2014, Rihanna left Def Jam Recordings to sign fully with JAY-Z’s Roc Nation.

2015 saw Rihanna’s return to making solo music, releasing singles like “FourFiveSeconds,” “Bitch Better Have My Money” and “American Oxygen.” The following year, in 2016, she released her eighth studio album ANTI.

In 2017, Rih featured in numerous hit songs like Kendrick Lamar’s “LOYALTY” and DJ Khaled’s “Wild Thoughts.” That same year, she announced she began working on her ninth studio album and that it will be released in 2019.

With all her hard work, Rihanna has become one of the most awarded artists in history, winning 214 in total. Of these awards include nine Grammy Awards, twelve Billboard Music Awards, thirteen American Music Awards, and seven MTV Video Music Awards.

Aside from music, Rihanna has ventured into other affairs like acting, starring in big movies like Ocean’s 8, This Is the End, Battleship, and the animated cartoon Home. Rih also launched the highly successful cosmetics brand, Fenty Beauty, in 2017 and was also appointed as an Ambassador of Barbados in 2018.

songs.title: Work

description.plain:
On “Work,” Rihanna seeks a deep, meaningful connection, however the male character she sings to (played by Drake) is only interested in sex. This narrative is similar to Rihanna and Drake’s previous collaborations, 2010’s “What’s My Name?” and 2011’s “Take Care.”

The song has a distinct dancehall vibe. Rihanna uses Jamaican Patois throughout, with terms like “work” (sex), “haffi” (have to) and “ah go” (going to) appearing in the hook.

Rihanna described her dialect in the song in Vogue’s April 2016 cover story:

You get what I’m saying, but it’s not all the way perfect. Because that’s how we speak in the Caribbean.

On “Work” co-star Drake, Rih added: “Everything he does is so amazing. We would go to in the Caribbean and just dance and drink and smoke and flirt.”

Snippets of “Work” began to circulate in January 2016 after the pair were spotted shooting a music video in an L.A. mall. On January 26th, Power 106 DJ Justin Credible tweeted that the  collaboration between Drake and Rihanna would be coming sooner than anticipated.

One of the song’s producers, Allen Ritter, told Genius that the song originally came together at a pool party at Drake’s house.

Both official “Work” videos were released on February 22, 2016.

songs.title: Needed Me

description.plain:
“Needed Me” is a mid-tempo mood piece with raw lyrics set over top of dark fluttery synth sounds produced by DJ Mustard. Rihanna provides a solid female empowerment anthem with this one (per her fans on Twitter).



It’s basically 3 minutes and 12 seconds of Rihanna serving tea.



This song was cowritten by singer-songwriter Starrah—who’s worked with Jeremih, Kid Ink, and G-Eazy—and Prince Charlez—who’s written for Usher, Enrique Iglesias, and the Backstreet Boys.

songs.title: Stay

description.plain:
“Stay” is the second single off of Rihanna’s seventh studio album Unapologetic.  It features guest vocals from Mikky Ekko and was written by Ekko and Justin Parker.

With this gorgeous piano ballad, Rihanna puts a vulnerable spin on the Brown situation, repeating another theme of the album – failing to resist true love. She inspires melancholy and raw emotion with this track, and never fails to convey her honesty with her lyrics and her delivery.

Chartwise, “Stay” was incredibly successful, moving over 10 million units all together, making it Rih’s third most successful single after Love the Way You Lie with Eminem and We Found Love with Calvin Harris.

body.plain:
“Stay” is the second single off of Rihanna’s seventh studio album Unapologetic.  It features guest vocals from Mikky Ekko and was written by Ekko and Justin Parker.

With this gorgeous piano ballad, Rihanna puts a vulnerable spin on the Brown situation, repeating another theme of the album – failing to resist true love. She inspires melancholy and raw emotion with this track, and never fails to convey her honesty with her lyrics and her delivery.

Chartwise, “Stay” was incredibly successful, moving over 10 million units all together, making it Rih’s third most successful single after Love the Way You Lie with Eminem and We Found Love with Calvin Harris.

songs.title: Kiss It Better

description.plain:
“Kiss It Better” tells the story of a broken relationship. She is aware that no one does it like him so instead of arguing all night she ‘kisses it better’.

A preview of the song first appeared in December 2014—over a year before the release of Anti—on Rihanna’s Instagram page, featuring guitarist Nuno Bettencourt.

https://www.instagram.com/p/wZn2FQBMxx/

In December 2015, a few weeks before the album’s release, the song’s producer, Glass John, took to Twitter and ranted about the delays behind Rihanna’s album. According to Glass John, “Kiss It Better” was supposed to be the first single for Anti, but Travi$ Scott convinced Rihanna to go with “Bitch Better Have My Money” instead. (Travi$ denied John’s claims on Snapchat.)

https://twitter.com/glassjohn/status/680966123911647232
https://twitter.com/glassjohn/status/680966232753885184
https://twitter.com/GlassJohn/status/680964390120628224?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

John also released a now-deleted 60-second video preview of the track and threatened, “if you don’t say your [sic] sorry "Kiss It Better” isn’t going to come out… how about that?"

According to James Corden, the host of CBS' The Late Late Show With James Corden, Rihanna was supposed to perform this song at the 2016 Grammys. Rihanna ended up cancelling her performance at the last minute due to health issues.

On 31 March 2016, Rihanna released the music video for “Kiss It Better” via her official Vevo account.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=49lY0HqqUVc

songs.title: Sex with Me

description.plain:
In “Sex With Me”, Rihanna makes it clear that having sex with her is something unique; in fact, it’s luxurious and, according to her, “so amazing.”

Rih has definitely mentioned the act on many songs, namely “Birthday Cake”, “Cockiness (Love It)”, “S&M”, “Push Up On Me”, “Watch N' Learn”, and “You Da One.”

On ANTi, she mentions sex multiple times, but it’s different here. Instead of being generally vague lyrics, these are more raw and personal—and just more sexy.

songs.title: Bitch Better Have My Money

description.plain:
Also stylized as “BBHMM”, “Bitch Better Have My Money” is Rihanna’s second single off her eighth album Anti. The title comes from a scene in the 1988 film I’m Gonna Git You Sucka.

The image used for the single’s cover art seems to come from a shoot Rihanna had in December 2014 in Paris where she modeled a similar look for Paolo Roversi.



On July 1, the highly anticipated 7 minute explicit video was released. Co-directed by Rihanna and French director Megaforce, the video follows the story of Rihanna and her two accomplices kidnapping and torturing a rich accountant’s wife for ransom. It stars Mads Mikkelsen as the accountant. Eric Roberts also makes an appearance as a police officer.

songs.title: Consideration

description.plain:
On “Consideration,” Rihanna considers the scope of her career. She wants to be considered a serious artist, not just an entertainer. To Rih Rih this means writing and producing her own work.

On ANTi (her eighth album), Rihanna has a writing credit on every song aside from “Same Ol' Mistakes,” while on her fifth album Loud, she has zero. The appearance of SZA makes this one of only two features ANTi.

Kuk Harrell and Tyran Donaldson’s classic dusty boombap-style hip-hop beat samples the bass line from Common’s “Be (Intro).”

Although the song served as the perfect opener for ANTI it was originally intended to be on SZA’s 2017 album Ctrl. In an interview with i-D Magazine , SZA said she performed the song for Rihanna and Pharrell during a writing camp and was reluctant to give it up. SZA even attributed the loss of “Consideration” as part of the reason her own album was so delayed. In the interview she said:

CTRL probably would have been completed a year earlier had I kept Consideration. That was the centerpiece. I shot a video for it and everything.

songs.title: Diamonds

description.plain:
“Diamonds” was released as the lead single from Rihanna’s seventh studio album, Unapologetic. It became her twelfth number-one in the US.

The song was written by Sia, who wrote the chart topping hit in just 14 minutes.


We’re sitting there trying to make records, and we finally just said, ‘Let’s just do something we like. Let’s make a hip-hop record with some really cool chords on it… It didn’t sound Rihanna at all. We were more thinking of making a record that sounds like Kanye. Let’s make a record with a dope beat. So we did. Then Sia heard the track and instantly gravitated towards it. We weren’t even thinking of putting a pop song on it, but she wrote this amazing song.“
––Benny Blanco (Producer)

I literally punched him in the arm. I thought Benny was playing a trick on me, [Rihanna] could’ve done it her own way, but I think she really genuinely liked the way it was.“
––Sia

songs.title: Desperado

description.plain:
Rihanna sings about a “desperado"—someone "on the run,” either literally or metaphorically. She struggles in their relationship and wonders whether she can run away with him or if she will get left behind.

The beat on “Desperado” is an interpolation of the background vocals on alternative-R&B singer Banks‘ song “Waiting Game”.

The song’s producer, Mike Schultz, said that he wanted the song to sound “edgy.”

I like to do different things and try to push the envelope on sound. If you listen to the record, it’s got an alternative vibe but still has urban undertones but it’s guitar and dirty live bass. I was just trying to do something edgy. I’m into doing dark, edgy stuff that moves you, puts you in a mood.

songs.full_title: Desperado (Good Times Ahead Remix) by Rihanna
songs.title: Desperado (Good Times Ahead Remix)

body.plain:
Rihanna sings about a “desperado"—someone "on the run,” either literally or metaphorically. She struggles in their relationship and wonders whether she can run away with him or if she will get left behind.

The beat on “Desperado” is an interpolation of the background vocals on alternative-R&B singer Banks‘ song “Waiting Game”.

The song’s producer, Mike Schultz, said that he wanted the song to sound “edgy.”

I like to do different things and try to push the envelope on sound. If you listen to the record, it’s got an alternative vibe but still has urban undertones but it’s guitar and dirty live bass. I was just trying to do something edgy. I’m into doing dark, edgy stuff that moves you, puts you in a mood.

songs.title: Same Ol’ Mistakes

description.plain:
“Same Ol’ Mistakes,” is a cover of Tame Impala’s 2015  Currents closer “New Person, Same Old Mistakes.”

During the making of ANTi Rihanna said she wanted  “songs that I could perform in 15 years; I wanted an album that I could perform in 15 years, not any songs that were burnt out.”



Tame Impala’s team issued a statement to NME about Rihanna’s cover:

The Roc Nation team got in touch with us here at Spinning Top letting us know that Rihanna loved… ‘'New Person, Same Old Mistakes.’ They asked if she could cover the song for her new record. Kevin was more than happy to send it her way. We’re all really happy with how the song turned out, love it!

songs.title: What’s My Name?

description.plain:
On “What’s My Name?” Drake and Rihanna trade romantic bars about their lovers. In the music video, they play the love interests for each other.

The collaboration was originally planned to be a remix and the solo version to be on Loud but it made the final cut. Ester Dean originally wrote a demo for the song before it was sent to Rihanna to be re-recorded for her album.

The song became an instant hit, eventually giving Rih her eighth number-one and Drake his first. It’s also certified 6x platinum by the RIAA.

Higher

description.plain:
According to songwriter Bibi Bourelly, “Higher” was written in only 20 minutes.  She spoke to Vice about the song:

Everything happens for a reason. Working with Rihanna has changed my life. The 20 minutes it took me to write “Higher” is actually what changed my life, because, even though we wrote “Bitch Better Have My Money” first, she heard that one first.

The intoxicating ANTI track first surfaced in March 2015 as a pair of Instagram previews posted by Rihanna while drunk on whiskey at 5:00 AM.

Rihanna compared the song to “a drunk voicemail” in Vogue’s April 2016 cover story:

You know he’s wrong, and then you get drunk and you’re like, ‘I could forgive him. I could call him. I could make up with him.’ Just, desperate.

songs.title: Love the Way You Lie, Pt. II
songs.title_with_featured: Love the Way You Lie, Pt. II (Ft. Eminem)

description.plain:
A sequel to the original Eminem/Rihanna collaboration “Love the Way You Lie”, this song instead looks at the situation from the female perspective, with Rihanna taking lead this time around.

Following the release and commercial success of the original Eminem felt they should record a sequel to/an alternate version of the song. In an interview with MTV, Rihanna stated that initially she was “very against” recording a sequel, saying:

When I first heard the idea about doing a part two, I was just completely against it. I just felt like you couldn’t beat the original. There’s no way you can outdo that, so why compete with it?

She went on to say that when she heard the original “broken down” demo version of the song in the studio with Eminem, sung by American singer-songwriter Skylar Grey, all of her reservations about recording it went away.

See the original Skylar Grey demo below:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=awJS4GYyYeA

songs.title: Umbrella

description.plain:
Rihanna comforts her lover by telling him she will be there for him, in good times and bad. The umbrella is a metaphor for her support.

“Umbrella” stayed on top of the UK Singles Chart for 10 consecutive weeks, longer than any other single that decade. The single remained at the top of the US Billboard Hot 100 for seven consecutive weeks.

The accompanying music video, directed by Chris Applebaum, was released on May 11, 2007.

In 2008, “Umbrella” won a Grammy for Best Rap/Sung Collaboration, and was nominated for Record of the Year and Song of the Year. It won two MTV Music Video awards in 2007, but was nominated for three. This song is number 412 on Rolling Stone’s 500 Greatest Songs of All Time.

Mary J. Blige revealed in an interview that this song was actually written by The-Dream and Tricky Stewart for her:

They did the song for me. And it was during the Grammy time and I was really, really busy, and I heard it, and I was like, ‘Oh my goodness, that’s a smash. I love this song.’ And it was like, ‘It’s yours.’ So in the midst of it being mine, they were probably telling [Rihanna] it was hers. She’s such a beautiful lady, and I love her to death. I was so glad that she caught it and knocked it out of the park, and it’s still one of my favorite songs to date.

When Chris Brown and Rihanna were still dating, he recorded his own version of this song. He changed the chorus to “You can be my Cinderella.”

album.full_title: Good Girl Gone Bad by Rihanna
album.name: Good Girl Gone Bad

body.plain:
Rihanna comforts her lover by telling him she will be there for him, in good times and bad. The umbrella is a metaphor for her support.

“Umbrella” stayed on top of the UK Singles Chart for 10 consecutive weeks, longer than any other single that decade. The single remained at the top of the US Billboard Hot 100 for seven consecutive weeks.

The accompanying music video, directed by Chris Applebaum, was released on May 11, 2007.

In 2008, “Umbrella” won a Grammy for Best Rap/Sung Collaboration, and was nominated for Record of the Year and Song of the Year. It won two MTV Music Video awards in 2007, but was nominated for three. This song is number 412 on Rolling Stone’s 500 Greatest Songs of All Time.

Mary J. Blige revealed in an interview that this song was actually written by The-Dream and Tricky Stewart for her:

They did the song for me. And it was during the Grammy time and I was really, really busy, and I heard it, and I was like, ‘Oh my goodness, that’s a smash. I love this song.’ And it was like, ‘It’s yours.’ So in the midst of it being mine, they were probably telling [Rihanna] it was hers. She’s such a beautiful lady, and I love her to death. I was so glad that she caught it and knocked it out of the park, and it’s still one of my favorite songs to date.

When Chris Brown and Rihanna were still dating, he recorded his own version of this song. He changed the chorus to “You can be my Cinderella.”

songs.title: Close to You

description.plain:
Album-closer “Close to You” is a haunting piano ballad reminiscent of Rihanna’s 2012 stand-out track “Stay.” Lyrically, the song deals with the singer’s struggle  to move on from a past love.

Frequent Rihanna-collaborator and co-writer for “Close to You,” James Fauntleroy talked about the making of this R&B ballad:


Whenever I’m writing songs for Rihanna, I’m always thinking about specific things that we all know about her, but I’m also trying to make it something that everyone can relate to. “Close to You” is about some things that I know she feels but that people also feel in general.

When you’re thinking of any famous person that’s had a relationship in the media, you remember that everybody has had that feeling and moment when they’re alone and feeling sad. But people are more likely to pretend that nothing is wrong with them than the opposite.

songs.lyrics:
Nothing but a tear, that's all for breakfast
Watching you pretend you're unaffected
You're pulling our connections, expecting me to let you go
But I won't

I know you don't need my protection
But I'm in love, can't blame me for checking
I love in your direction, hoping that the message goes

Somewhere close to you
Close to you
Like so close if they hurt you, you wouldn't find out
Just say now, I'm coming right now to be close to you

Said you let it go, you kept it
Working hard to perfect it
But now your fear is reckless, and it's out of your control
Well just let it go

I know you don't need my protection
But I'm in love, can't blame me for checking
I love in your direction, hoping that the message goes

Somewhere close to you
Close to you
Like so close, if they hurt you, you wouldn't find out
If you let me, I'd be there by now
Close to you

songs.title: Woo

description.plain:
“Woo” is the  only track with a credited feature from Rihanna’s rumored-boyfriend Travis Scott. Abel Tesfaye (The Weeknd) is credited as one of the track’s composers/lyricists. His demo of the song was leaked online on June 7, 2018.



Like other songs on ANTi, “Woo” is a breakup track. In the first verse, Rihanna expresses  contempt towards her ex and his new flame. She exudes her trademark confidence with lines like, “Bet she could never make you cry/Cause the scars on your heart are still mine.”

As the track progresses, Rihanna’s vulnerability comes to the surface, until she finally admits, “I don’t really mean to love ya / I don’t really mean to care about ya, no more.”
